_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for the Eastern Gas Transmission and Storage, Inc.'s (EGTS) Lightburn Extraction Plant (LEP).  Eastern Gas Transmission and Storage, Inc. (EGTS) operates the facility which is owned by Eastern Gathering and Processing, Inc. (EGP).



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:

EGTS is committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility. It is EGTS's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. If a release does occur, regular personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. EGTS has contracted Weavertown Environmental Group as an Oil/Spill Response Organization to provide additional emergency response expertise. Also, EGTS will contact the Lewis County Emergency Dispatch to obtain additional resources from local volunteer fire departments, law enforcement and emergency medical services.



The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:

Stationary Source, Regulated Substances Handled & Covered Process:

LEP is a natural gas extraction plant that receives raw natural gas and processes it to remove free liquids from the gas. The gas is compressed and dehydrated utilizing a molecular sieve bed. After dehydration the pressure is reduced, and the gas is cooled through the expander side of the expander/compressor. The gas is sent to an absorber where liquids condense and fall to the bottom. The overhead gas is warmed, compressed, and sent back

to Eastern Gas Transmission and Storage's (EGTS's) transmission pipeline system. The mixed natural gas liquid (NGL) product containing pentane, isopentane [butane, 2-methyl], butane, isobutane [propane, 2-methyl], propane, and ethane is sent to one of the four 60,000-gallon product storage tanks. The NGL product is a flammable mixture that meets the NFPA-4 criteria and is present onsite in a process in an amount that exceeds the threshold quantity (10,000 pounds) for applicability under the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements. No regulated toxic substances above the threshold quantity are present at the facility.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:

EGTS has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68 of the EPA. LEP was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME B31.3. LEP is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119 and is classified as a Program 3 process under USEPA's RMP. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at this facility.



Process Safety Information - EGTS personnel maintain a detailed record of process safety information that describes the hazards of regulated substances, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the regulated process. Much of this information was compiled during the preparation of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). The OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (HCS) requires chemical manufacturers, distributors or importers to provide SDSs to communicate the hazards of hazar

dous chemical products.



Process Hazard Analysis - EGTS personnel conduct comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the regulated process are identified and controlled efficiently. EGTS primarily uses the What-If and HAZOP method analysis techniques to perform these hazard evaluations. The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will be revalidated at regular intervals of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

 

Operating Procedures - For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered process, EGTS maintains written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with process safety. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. Safe work practices have been developed to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to employees and contractor employees.



Training - EGTS has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Initial employee training is provided, and refresher training is conducted at least every three years or more frequently as needed. Employee training is documented, and a record of training is maintained onsite for at least three years.



Mechanical Integrity - Written procedures are in place for mainta

ining the on-going integrity of process equipment, which incorporates training for process maintenance activities, inspection and testing, corrective action for equipment deficiencies, and the application of quality assurance measures. Documented maintenance checks are carried out on process equipment to ensure proper operation and maintenance. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified and trained personnel carry out maintenance operations at the site. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. LEP also incorporates quality assurance measures to ensure that equipment and parts are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.



Management of Change - Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. These procedures are updated as needed. Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of any process changes and are offered training to deal with modifications.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews - Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at LEP. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction and installed equipment meet design specifications, and that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits - Regularly scheduled audits are conducted to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being properly implemented. The audits are conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and are conducted at least every three years. Audit findings a

re documented in a report and corrective actions are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. LEP maintains a record of the two most recent compliance audit reports. 



Incident Investigation - Any incident that results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance will be promptly investigated. An incident investigation will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours after the incident, and will involve at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and will include any resolutions and corrective actions. All incident reports are retained for a minimum of five years.



Employee Participation - EGTS believes that PSM and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.



Hot Work Permit - LEP personnel will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process. The permit shall document that the fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations; it shall indicate the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identify the object on which hot work is to be performed. The permit will be kept on file until completion of the hot work operations.



Contractors - EGTS hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out and before any contractors perform work at LEP,

they undergo an orientation. During this orientation contractors are made aware of the known potential hazards related the contractor's work, the hazards of regulated substances, and the safe work procedures insisted on by EGTS. In addition, they are familiarized with the Hot Work Permit Policy and the Lock Out/Tag Out Procedures. Contractors are further informed of all the procedures for emergency response, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. Emergency response information includes evacuation routes and personnel assembly points. EGTS documents that all contract personnel have received and understood the training.



Chemical Specific Prevention Steps - The covered process at LEP has hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. Collectively, the prevention program activities described above help prevent potential accidental scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human error. In addition, LEP incorporates safety features on its equipment to help (a) contain/control a release (e.g., diking and enclosures); (b) quickly detect a release (e.g., hydrocarbon detectors with alarms), and (c) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release (e.g., fire suppression and extinguishing).



The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:

LEP has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.



The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:

EGTS maintains a SharePoint website for Site Specific Emergency Plans (SSEP) for emergency response information on individual sites. This website is readily available for use on employee computer terminals and the emergency response plan is also conspicuously posted on bulletin boards for immediate access should an emergency response be required. Each written SSEP has an emergency plan that addresses accidental releases of regulated substances and is in place to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.



The plan includes actions to be

taken including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, and notifications to local emergency response agencies and the public. To ensure proper function, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response. In the event of an emergency, EGTS will immediately notify 911 (Lewis County 911 Operations Center and Emergency Management). The responders will coordinate emergency response activities.



The emergency plan has been coordinated with the Lewis/Upshur County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:

EGTS is committed to continuous improvement and looks for opportunities to improve safety systems and programs at the facility.
